clean_story:
Space rocks. Life’s cosmic hitchhike.


"Lithopanspermia" comes from Greek lithos (stone) and panspermia (seeds everywhere). It’s the idea that life could travel between planets inside meteorites—like a seed riding a rock through space. <[silence:2400]

Most think life started on Earth. But what if it arrived here? A violent asteroid impact could blast microbes into space, frozen inside rock. These "space seeds" might drift for millions of years, surviving radiation and cold, until gravity pulls them to a new world. <[silence:2400]

In 1996, scientists found possible fossilized microbes in a Martian meteorite called ALH84001. Tests showed it had been floating in space for 16 million years. No proof of life—but proof rocks can carry tiny passengers. <[silence:2400]

Extreme life on Earth thrives in volcanoes, deep ice, even nuclear waste. If microbes can survive there, why not in a space rock? Experiments show some bacteria endure years in orbit. <[silence:2400]

Could Earth’s first life have been a space traveler? Or did we send life to Mars on our own rovers? The universe might be a vast, slow game of microbial tag.

Tardigrades. Interstellar dust. The Fermi Paradox.
